subject: Gardening
title: Pollinators Beyond Honeybees
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Pollinators Beyond Honeybees.

hook.text: Honeybees get all the attention. But wild bees, flies, beetles, and butterflies do most of the world's pollination.

buildup.text: Over 20,000 bee species exist. Honeybees are just one. Bumblebees, mason bees, and mining bees do vital work.

discovery.text: Bumblebees pollinate tomatoes better than honeybees. They vibrate at a frequency that shakes pollen loose.

twist.text: Managed honeybee colonies can outcompete wild pollinators for resources, potentially harming the diversity gardens need.

climax.text: Supporting wild pollinators through diverse planting and nesting habitat is more important than keeping honeybees.

punchline.text: Wild bees do the real pollination work. Support them.

quiz.question: Why are bumblebees better than honeybees at pollinating tomatoes?
options: They visit tomato flowers more frequently due to color preference
They use buzz pollination, vibrating at frequencies that release tomato pollen
Their longer tongues can reach deeper into tomato flower structures
